title: Presentations
text:
MCEVBD job interview
I gave this  presentation  as part of my job interview for my current job at the MCEVBD. This presentation was made with LaTeX. The raw code can be found see here and downloaded here.
PhD defense talk
I gave this  presentation  as part of my PhD defense at the University of Zurich. This presentation was made with LaTeX. The raw code can be found here.

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (1)

Keep an as raw as possible version

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (1)

Keep an as raw as possible version
Consider making your original data file read-only



keep in a ‘save’ format
Not excel format - transferring between platforms can cause an issue (e.g. dates)
csv, tsv, maybe text



Don’t make changes to this raw data

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (2)

Content of columns in correct data type and units

character (e.g, “a”, “swc”)
numeric (real or decimal) (e.g, 2, 2.0)
logical (FALSE, TRUE)
integer (e.g, 2L, as.integer(3))
complex (e.g, 1 + 0i, 1 + 4i) <- These can be annoying




R sees logical as 0/1 (FALSE/TRUE). This can be handy during coding.

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (3)

Try to have content of columns in correct data type and units
An example why this can is important



speciesspeedspeed_mphelphant24.0 mph24.0mouse8.1 mph8.1cheetah74.6 mph74.7

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (4)

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling

title: Good data practices
text:
Data documentation (2)

README

one per dataset
provide a title for the dataset
brief description per column
publicly available data may need more details
https://guides.lib.uci.edu/datamanagement/readme

Metadata

often 1 per study
information does generally not change

e.g. details on study sites

data about data




https://datadryad.org/stash/best_practices https://data.research.cornell.edu/content/readme

title: Good data practices
text:
Naming

Use descriptive names for folders, files and variables


Understandable but not to long

m1 versus glm_count_full
data versus tick_counts_EA








Tip


While a computer will ultimately run your code, it’ll be read by humans, so write code intended for humans!

title: Good data practices
text:
Naming

Be aware on naming rules of programs

Avoid special characters ($, @, *)
Avoid name of functions
No spaces !!
Case-sensitive (e.g. R) versus case insensitive (SQL)
R (and many other languages) names can’t start with numbers and does not like spaces
‘car speed in miles per hour’ versus ‘car speed (mph)’ versus car_speed_mph’

section: How to deal with R (programming) errors
text:
How to deal with R (programming) errors

don’t get frustrated by error messages
read the error message
google the error message
google solutions or use ChatGPT
trial and error

it works –> go back to your analysis

error -> go back to 1.

title: Introduction into git
text: What is version control

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is version control

Keep track and saves all you changes to code
Good backup source
Easier to fix mistakes
Code is open and easy to share
Multiple people working on the same code

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is Git

Git is a version control system that allows developers to track changes in their code
installed on your own computer
controlled through mostly terminal

but e.g. Rstudio have systems to make it easier

there are alternatives but git is most common (at least in science)

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is GitHub

GitHub is a web-based hosting service for git repositories.
Enables you to store and share code for different projects
More advanced

Github actions
Github pages
Together they can e.g. build and host a webpage (e.g. this presentation).

title: Introduction into git
text: Let’s have some fun !!

title: Introduction into git
text:
Let’s have some fun
Sorry I forgot I am in an mosquito lab

title: Introduction into git
text:
First steps

Make an account

https://github.com/signup

Install git

https://github.com/git-guides/install-git

Github student account
private repositories

title: Introduction into git
text:
Make a repository

Method 1 (easy)

Create repository on github
https://github.com

Method 2 (harder)

use Git Repo

Create a repository from command line
Not today

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal

‘Easy’ start with git bash

https://education.github.com/git-cheat-sheet-education.pdf
Let’s go to the terminal.

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal
echo "# training_repo" >> README.md
git init
git add README.md
git commit -m "first commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin git@github.com:david-awam-jansen/training_repo.git
git push -u origin main

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
The start

Write paper

title: Introduction into peer review process
text: Keep working on it

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
First review

Have people look at the paper (e.g. writing workshop)
Add page and line numbers
Send to PIs

Send to co-authors (give them a heads-up)

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Don’t forget

Decide on journal

scope
impact factor
similar work

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Step 2

Check the author guidelines of the journal

Journal of Medical Entomology
Tick and Tick-borne Diseases
Current Biology

title: Introduction into peer review process
section: Get ready for the exciting step
text: Get ready for the exciting step

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Sorry one more thing

Check paper

Are all references there?
Spelling and grammar check
Journal Formatting
Check figures and tables

title: Introduction into peer review process
text: Get ready

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Get ready

Check everything one more time

title: Introduction into peer review process
text: Peer review process

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Submission

Cover letter

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Submission

Cover letters

Plos Biology
Plos one

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Submission

Cover letter
Have everything ready. Often specific formats it needs to be submitted

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Receiving reviewer comments

Good reviewers make your paper better
If rejected still look at comments and do something with them
Very often major or minor revisions needed

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Receiving reviewer comments

Revisions required

Read all comments first
Share with co-authors (also ask if you need help with specific comments)
Respond to all comments and keep track of changes
Generally a limited turn around period
Jansen et al paper

Rejected

Still, read all the comments

Why was the paper rejected?

Generally, still, revise paper
Habig et al paper

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Respond to reviewer comments

Respond to all comments

Point by point
Track changes on the document
All co-authors should read responses and agree
Include a cover letter to the editor
Major revision Jansen et al BMC paper

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Proofing paper

Paper is accepted
Copy editors will format paper They are probrably not scientists
Jansen et al BMC paper proofing request

First time you see your final paper :-)

Jansen et al BMC paper proof document

Read whole paper
Check details

references
figures and tables (captions)
scientific names and notations
author names and affiliations

Jansen et al BMC paper comments to proof

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
What is ggplot2?

Definition: ggplot2 is an R package for creating data visualizations based on the grammar of graphics.
Created by: Hadley Wickham
First released: 2007

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

Advantages:

Produces visually appealing and customizable plots.
Based on a coherent grammar of graphics, making it easy to understand and use.
Works well with tidy data principles.
Offers extensive documentation and a large community of users.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

Grammar of Graphics: A systematic way to describe the components of a graph, including data, aesthetics, and geometric objects.
Layered Grammar: Allows you to build complex plots by adding layers of data and visual elements.
Faceting: Easily create multiple plots based on subsets of your data.
Themes: Customize the appearance of your plots with built-in or custom themes.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

There are many package that build on ggplot to work with specific kinds of data, e.g.;

survminer for survival analysis
ggcorrplot for correlation plots
gganimate make plot animations

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Basic Syntax Overview

ggplot() function: Initializes a ggplot object.
data Can be given either directly or through a pipe
aes() function: Specifies aesthetic mappings between data variables and visual properties.
geom_*() functions: Add geometric objects (points, lines, bars, etc.) to your plot.
facet_*() functions: Facet your plot by one or more variables.
theme() function: Customize the appearance of your plot.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Data prep for plotting

Generally data needs to be in a long format
Columns need top be in format you want to plot


library(tidyverse)

tibble(location = c("A", "B"),
       week1 = c(10, 12),
       week2 = c(12, 15),
       week3 = c(14, 15),
       week4 = c(11,  20)) %>% 
  flextable::flextable()

locationweek1week2week3week4A10121411B12151520

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Data prep for plotting

Generally data needs to be in a long format


df <- tibble(location = c("A", "B"),
       week1 = c(10, 12),
       week2 = c(12, 15),
       week3 = c(14, 15),
       week4 = c(11,  20)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(names_to = "week", values_to = "count", week1:week4) %>%  
  mutate(week = as.numeric(str_remove(week, pattern = "week"))) 


df %>% 
  flextable::flextable()

locationweekcountA110A212A314A411B112B215B315B420

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (1)

basic plot


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count)) +
  geom_point()

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (2)

change size of the dots


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count)) +
  geom_point(size = 5)

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (3)

change the color of the dots


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5)

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (4)

change axis


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,22))

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (5)

change labels and theme


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,22)) +
  labs(x = "sample week", y = "tick count") +
  theme_classic()

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text: Zack’s heatmap

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Zack’s heatmap (code)

ggplot(data = heatmap_data, aes(x = week, y = transect, fill = density)) +
    geom_tile() +
    facet_grid(treatment_type ~ .) +
    scale_fill_gradient(low = "white", high = "black") +
    guides(fill = guide_colorbar(title = "Density of nymphs per 1000m2"))  +
    labs(y = "") +
    theme(legend.position = "bottom",
                legend.key.size = unit(1, 'cm')) +
    theme(panel.background = element_blank(),
                plot.background = element_blank(),
                axis.text = element_text(size = 19))+
    geom_vline(xintercept = c(1.5, 5.5), linetype = "dashed", size = 1.5) +
    theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 16),
                legend.text = element_text(size = 16),
                legend.title = element_text(size = 19),
                title = element_text(size = 15),
                strip.text = element_text(size = 15))

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Resources

chatgpt and google
find examples and build from there
useful webpages

https://r-statistics.co/Top50-Ggplot2-Visualizations-MasterList-R-Code.html
https://ggplot2tor.com/theme/
https://r-graph-gallery.com/
https://rstudio.github.io/cheatsheets/html/data-visualization.html

R Graphics Cookbook (I have a copy)
ask me (I love making visualizations)

I am data scientist at the Midwest Center of Excellence for Vector-Borne Disease (MCEVBD) https://mcevbd.wisc.edu/. I have a broad experience in behavioral research, database management, statistical modeling, and data visualization. I enjoy being a resource for my colleagues and providing advice on statistical modeling, coding, and research reproducibility. Prior to joining the center, I worked as a research scientist at the University of Notre Dame and the Amboseli Baboon Research Project.

I am data scientist at the Midwest Center of Excellence for Vector-Borne Disease (MCEVBD) https://mcevbd.wisc.edu/. I have a broad experience in behavioral research, database management, statistical modeling, and data visualization. I enjoy being a resource for my colleagues and providing advice on statistical modeling, coding, and research reproducibility. Prior to joining the center, I worked as a research scientist at the University of Notre Dame and the Amboseli Baboon Research Project.

Education
University of Zurich , Switzerland PhD in Animal communication | Sep 2009 - Apr 2013
Wageningen University, Netherlands MsC in Forest and Nature Management - Ecology | Aug 2003 - June 2005
Wageningen University, Netherlands BSc in Forest and Nature Management | Aug 2000 - June 2003
Click here for my Resume or CV

title: Publications list
text:
References

Akinyi, M. Y., Habig, B., Gesquiere, L. R., Alberts, S. C., & Archie, E. A. (2019). Costs and drivers of helminth parasite infection in wild female baboons. Journal of Animal Ecology, 88(7), 1029–1043.

title: David Jansen
text: The site is created with Rstudio and Quarto (https://quarto.org/docs/websites). It uses a Docker container to manage R packages and is maintained through github actions.

title: Introduction into git
text: What is version control

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is version control

Keep track and saves all you changes to code
Good backup source
Easier to fix mistakes
Code is open and easy to share
Multiple people working on the same code

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is Git

Git is a version control system that allows developers to track changes in their code
installed on your own computer
controlled through mostly terminal

but e.g. Rstudio have systems to make it easier

there are alternatives but git is most common (at least in science)

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is GitHub

GitHub is a web-based hosting service for git repositories.
Enables you to store and share code for different projects
More advanced

Github actions
Github pages
Together they can e.g. build and host a webpage (e.g. this presentation).

title: Introduction into git
text: Let’s have some fun !!

title: Introduction into git
text:
Let’s have some fun
Sorry I forgot I am in an mosquito lab

title: Introduction into git
text:
First steps

Make an account

https://github.com/signup

Install git

https://github.com/git-guides/install-git

Github student account
private repositories

title: Introduction into git
text:
Make a repository

Method 1 (easy)

Create repository on github
https://github.com

Method 2 (harder)

use Git Repo

Create a repository from command line
Not today

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal

‘Easy’ start with git bash

https://education.github.com/git-cheat-sheet-education.pdf
Let’s go to the terminal.

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal
echo "# training_repo" >> README.md
git init
git add README.md
git commit -m "first commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin git@github.com:david-awam-jansen/training_repo.git
git push -u origin main

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal
git status
git add
git commit

title: Introduction into git
text:
Rstudio examples

terminal
build-in

title: Introduction into git
text:
Naming

Use descriptive names for folders, files and variables


Understandable but not to long

m1 versus glm_count_full
data versus tick_counts_EA








Tip


While a computer will ultimately run your code, it’ll be read by humans, so write code intended for humans!

title: Introduction into git
text:
Naming

Be aware on naming rules of programs

Avoid special characters ($, @, *)
Avoid name of functions
No spaces !!
Case-sensitive (e.g. R) versus case insensitive (SQL)
R (and many other languages) names can’t start with numbers and does not like spaces
‘car speed in miles per hour’ versus ‘car speed (mph)’ versus car_speed_mph’

title: Introduction into git

Avoid name of functions

Case-sensitive (e.g. R) versus case insensitive (SQL)

‘car speed in miles per hour’ versus ‘car speed (mph)’ versus car_speed_mph’

be consistent

title: Introduction into git
section: How to deal with R (programming) errors
text:
How to deal with R (programming) errors

don’t get frustrated by error messages
read the error message
google the error message
google solutions or use ChatGPT
trial and error

it works –> go back to your analysis

error -> go back to 1.

Other sources
Noble WS. A quick guide to organizing computational biology projects. PLoS Comput Biol. 2009 Jul;5(7):e1000424. doi: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000424. http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000424

title: Dociteproc Example

title: Dociteproc Example
text:
Heading
This filter adds formatting to heading text.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
What is ggplot2?

Definition: ggplot2 is an R package for creating data visualizations based on the grammar of graphics.
Created by: Hadley Wickham
First released: 2007

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

Advantages:

Produces visually appealing and customizable plots.
Based on a coherent grammar of graphics, making it easy to understand and use.
Works well with tidy data principles.
Offers extensive documentation and a large community of users.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

Grammar of Graphics: A systematic way to describe the components of a graph, including data, aesthetics, and geometric objects.
Layered Grammar: Allows you to build complex plots by adding layers of data and visual elements.
Faceting: Easily create multiple plots based on subsets of your data.
Themes: Customize the appearance of your plots with built-in or custom themes.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

There are many package that build on ggplot to work with specific kinds of data, e.g.;

survminer for survival analysis
ggcorrplot for correlation plots
gganimate make plot animations

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Basic Syntax Overview

ggplot() function: Initializes a ggplot object.
data Can be given either directly or through a pipe
aes() function: Specifies aesthetic mappings between data variables and visual properties.
geom_*() functions: Add geometric objects (points, lines, bars, etc.) to your plot.
facet_*() functions: Facet your plot by one or more variables.
theme() function: Customize the appearance of your plot.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Data prep for plotting

Generally data needs to be in a long format
Columns need top be in format you want to plot


library(tidyverse)

tibble(location = c("A", "B"),
       week1 = c(10, 12),
       week2 = c(12, 15),
       week3 = c(14, 15),
       week4 = c(11,  20)) %>% 
  flextable::flextable()

locationweek1week2week3week4A10121411B12151520

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Data prep for plotting

Generally data needs to be in a long format


df <- tibble(location = c("A", "B"),
       week1 = c(10, 12),
       week2 = c(12, 15),
       week3 = c(14, 15),
       week4 = c(11,  20)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(names_to = "week", values_to = "count", week1:week4) %>%  
  mutate(week = as.numeric(str_remove(week, pattern = "week"))) 


df %>% 
  flextable::flextable()

locationweekcountA110A212A314A411B112B215B315B420

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (1)

basic plot


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count)) +
  geom_point()

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (2)

change size of the dots


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count)) +
  geom_point(size = 5)

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (3)

change the color of the dots


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5)

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (4)

change axis


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,22))

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (5)

change labels and theme


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,22)) +
  labs(x = "sample week", y = "tick count") +
  theme_classic()

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text: Zack’s heatmap

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Zack’s heatmap (code)

ggplot(data = heatmap_data, aes(x = week, y = transect, fill = density)) +
    geom_tile() +
    facet_grid(treatment_type ~ .) +
    scale_fill_gradient(low = "white", high = "black") +
    guides(fill = guide_colorbar(title = "Density of nymphs per 1000m2"))  +
    labs(y = "") +
    theme(legend.position = "bottom",
                legend.key.size = unit(1, 'cm')) +
    theme(panel.background = element_blank(),
                plot.background = element_blank(),
                axis.text = element_text(size = 19))+
    geom_vline(xintercept = c(1.5, 5.5), linetype = "dashed", size = 1.5) +
    theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 16),
                legend.text = element_text(size = 16),
                legend.title = element_text(size = 19),
                title = element_text(size = 15),
                strip.text = element_text(size = 15))
